query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Mentr’ io dubbiava per lo viso spento, 2 de la fulgida fiamma che lo spense 3 uscì un spiro che mi fece attento,
4 dicendo: «Intanto che tu ti risense 5 de la vista che haï in me consunta, 6 ben è che ragionando la compense.
query.result:
**English:**
1 While I was in doubt because of my extinguished sight, 2 from the radiant flame that extinguished it 3 came a breath that made me attentive,
4 saying: "In the meantime that you recover 5 from the sight that you have consumed in me, 6 it is good that you compensate for it by reasoning.
**Cornish:**
1 Tra ve omovyn rag an golwg marow, 2 a-dhyworth an tan ow tewles, 3 eth an eneth a wrug vy dhe brederi,
4 ow leverel: "Tra veth owth aswonya 5 a'n golwg owth eus yn y'm konsumi, 6 da yw da vyth owth omdhrehevel orth resoni."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Comincia dunque; e dì ove s’appunta 8 l’anima tua, e fa ragion che sia 9 la vista in te smarrita e non defunta:
10 perché la donna che per questa dia 11 regïon ti conduce, ha ne lo sguardo 12 la virtù ch’ebbe la man d’Anania».
query.result:
**English:**
7 Begin then; and say where your soul is fixed, 8 and suppose that the sight in you is lost and not dead:
9 because the lady who leads you through this divine 10 region has in her gaze 11 the power that Ananias's hand had.
**Cornish:**
7 Devedh an gwella; ha leverel le mayth 8 le mayth agas eneth, ha gwre resoni 9 bos an golwg yn marow, mes na dhifow:
10 rag an venen a'th ledyas dre an meneth 11 dowr, yn y golwg yma 12 an gallos o veu dhe dhorn Ananias.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Io dissi: «Al suo piacere e tosto e tardo 14 vegna remedio a li occhi, che fuor porte 15 quand’ ella entrò col foco ond’ io sempr’ ardo.
query.result:
**English:**
13 I said: "At her pleasure, soon or late, 14 let there come a remedy for my eyes, which were extinguished 15 when she entered with the fire with which I always burn.
**Cornish:**
13 Me a leveris: "Orth y hy plijadur, bys vyth po diwedh, 14 dheuthas remedy dhe'm lagha, a veu difow 15 pan eth yma gans an tan owth owth aswonya."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Lo ben che fa contenta questa corte, 17 Alfa e O è di quanta scrittura 18 mi legge Amore o lievemente o forte».
query.result:
**English:**
16 The good that makes this court content, 17 is Alpha and Omega of every scripture 18 that Love reads to me, softly or forcefully.
**Cornish:**
16 An da yw gwella an les ma lowen, 17 Alfa ha O yw a bub lyther 18 a lever Karante dh'ym, yn dowr po yn gryf.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 E io: «Per filosofici argomenti 26 e per autorità che quinci scende 27 cotale amor convien che in me si ’mprenti:
28 ché ’l bene, in quanto ben, come s’intende, 29 così accende amore, e tanto maggio 30 quanto più di bontate in sé comprende.
query.result:
**English:**
25 And I: "Through philosophical arguments 26 and through authority that descends from here, 27 such love must be imprinted in me:
28 because the good, insofar as it is understood as good, 29 thus kindles love, and all the more 30 the more goodness it comprises in itself.
**Cornish:**
25 Ha my: "Dre argumentiow filosofek 26 ha dre awtoritas a dheuth a-dhyworth, 27 karante ma a dheuth bos dhe'm emprennya:
28 rag an da, yn keverek avel da, kepar ha'n aswon, 29 yn keverek a dheuth owth aswonya karante, ha moy ages 30 kepar ha moy da yw ynno."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Dunque a l’essenza ov’ è tanto avvantaggio, 32 che ciascun ben che fuor di lei si trova 33 altro non è ch’un lume di suo raggio,
34 più che in altra convien che si mova 35 la mente, amando, di ciascun che cerne 36 il vero in che si fonda questa prova.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Therefore, to the essence where there is so much advantage, 32 that every good that is found outside of it 33 is nothing but a ray of its light,
34 more than to any other, the mind must be moved, loving, by each one who discerns 35 the truth on which this proof is founded.
**Cornish:**
31 Rag dhe'n essens le mayth kemmys avans, 32 pub tra da a-ves yw mes un goleudh a'y skler,
33 moy ages y'n dhe bub aral, yth yw dhe spyrys dhe'y movia, 34 ow karante, a bub onen a aswon 35 an wir ynno mayth an prof ma fondys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Tal vero a l’intelletto mïo sterne 38 colui che mi dimostra il primo amore 39 di tutte le sustanze sempiterne.
query.result:
**English:**
37 So truly to my intellect did shine forth 38 he who shows me the first love 39 of all the eternal substances.
**Cornish:**
37 Marow gwir dhe'm deall, sterennow 38 an hini a wra'm diskwedhes an kynsa karantez 39 a bub an substansow sempiternel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Sternel la voce del verace autore, 41 che dice a Moïsè, di sé parlando: 42 ‘Io ti farò vedere ogne valore’.
query.result:
**English:**
40 The voice of the true Author shone forth, 41 who, speaking of himself, said to Moses: 42 ‘I will show you every value’.
**Cornish:**
40 Sterennow leun an Gwir Awtour, 41 neb a leveris dhe Moyses, owth ow th'y honan: 42 ‘Y'm gweles pub travalja’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Sternilmi tu ancora, incominciando 44 l’alto preconio che grida l’arcano 45 di qui là giù sovra ogne altro bando».
query.result:
**English:**
43 You also shone forth to me, beginning 44 the high praise that proclaims the secret 45 from here below over every other edict.
**Cornish:**
43 Sterennow dhe'm, ow komprehendya 44 an ughel skon a lever an kevrinek 45 a-dhia owth owma dhe'n ughella oll banerow erel».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 E io udi’: «Per intelletto umano 47 e per autoritadi a lui concorde 48 d’i tuoi amori a Dio guarda il sovrano.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And I heard: “By human intellect 47 and by authority that agrees with it, 48 look to the sovereign of your loves towards God.
**Cornish:**
46 Ha my a glewas: “Dre deall denel 47 ha dre awtorita owth ow kordennya 48 dhe'gas karantezow dhe Dhew, sel an soveren”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Ma dì ancor se tu senti altre corde 50 tirarti verso lui, sì che tu suone 51 con quanti denti questo amor ti morde».
query.result:
**English:**
49 But tell me also if you feel other strings 50 pulling you towards him, so that you may sound 51 with how many teeth this love bites you.
**Cornish:**
49 Mes lever dhe'gas os teves tevi kordennow erel 50 owth ow tynna dhe'gas, marow ty a sona 51 gans pub dansow an karantez-ma owth ow'th kigha”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Non fu latente la santa intenzione 53 de l’aguglia di Cristo, anzi m’accorsi 54 dove volea menar mia professione.
query.result:
**English:**
52 The holy intention of the eagle of Christ was not hidden, 53 indeed I realized 54 where he wanted to lead my profession.
**Cornish:**
52 An sans intensek an erel a'n Krist na veu kudhes 53 ow, mes my a welas 54 le may hy a vynna henna'm professa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Però ricominciai: «Tutti quei morsi 56 che posson far lo cor volgere a Dio, 57 a la mia caritate son concorsi:
58 ché l’essere del mondo e l’esser mio, 59 la morte ch’el sostenne perch’ io viva, 60 e quel che spera ogne fedel com’ io,
61 con la predetta conoscenza viva, 62 tratto m’hanno del mar de l’amor torto, 63 e del diritto m’han posto a la riva.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Therefore I began again: “All those bitings 56 that can make the heart turn to God, 57 have concurred with my charity:
58 for the being of the world and my being, 59 the death that he suffered so that I may live, 60 and that which every faithful man hopes for as I do,
61 with the aforementioned living knowledge, 62 have drawn me from the sea of twisted love, 63 and have placed me on the shore of the right one.
**Cornish:**
55 Rag henna my a dhallathas: “Pub an morsi 56 a yll gwul an kalon trohe dhe Dhew, 57 dhe'm karantez yns i a-kordennya:
58 Rag bos an bys ha'm bos, 59 an marow a dhug owth ow veva, 60 ha henna a spyr pub den feythful dell ow,
61 Gans an geverel a-rag an wonvosow, 62 y'm tynnas a-dhia an mor a'n karantez kamm, 63 ha dhe'n gwir karantez y'm settyas war an glan”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Le fronde onde s’infronda tutto l’orto 65 de l’ortolano etterno, am’ io cotanto 66 quanto da lui a lor di bene è porto».
query.result:
**English:**
64 The leaves with which the entire orchard 65 of the eternal gardener is adorned, I love as much 66 as the good that is given to them by him.
**Cornish:**
64 An deliow may hy a wra'n gwydh pub an arloedh 65 a'n areler byth, y'm karas kemmys 66 ha'n da dhodho dhe'n deliow a-dhia dhodho gans an areler”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Sì com’ io tacqui, un dolcissimo canto 68 risonò per lo cielo, e la mia donna 69 dicea con li altri: «Santo, santo, santo!».
query.result:
**English:**
67 As I fell silent, a most sweet song 68 resounded through heaven, and my lady 69 said with the others: “Holy, holy, holy!”.
**Cornish:**
67 Dell owth ow th'y thasow, kan milis a gana 68 a sonas dre'n nef, ha'm benenes 69 a leveris gans an erel: “Sans, sans, sans!”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 E come a lume acuto si disonna 71 per lo spirto visivo che ricorre 72 a lo splendor che va di gonna in gonna,
73 e lo svegliato ciò che vede aborre, 74 sì nescïa è la sùbita vigilia 75 fin che la stimativa non soccorre;
76 così de li occhi miei ogne quisquilia 77 fugò Beatrice col raggio d’i suoi, 78 che rifulgea da più di mille milia:
79 onde mei che dinanzi vidi poi; 80 e quasi stupefatto domandai 81 d’un quarto lume ch’io vidi tra noi.
query.result:
**English:**
70 And as one is awakened from sleep 71 by the visual spirit that runs 72 to the brightness that goes from skirt to skirt,
73 and the awakened one abhors what he sees, 74 so foolish is the sudden waking 75 until the faculty of judgment comes to the rescue;
76 thus Beatrice, with the ray of her eyes, 77 chased away every trifle from my eyes, 78 that shone from more than a thousand miles away:
79 so that I saw more afterwards than before; 80 and almost astounded I asked 81 about a fourth light that I saw among us.
**Cornish:**
70 Ha dell owth ow th'y thasow, den a dhiskudh 71 dre'n speris gwelus a wra'n ow resek 72 dhe'n splannder a wra'n ow mos a-dhia gonow,
73 ha'n den a dhiskudh a gasa henna a wel, 74 marow fol yw an diskudh dhesempys 75 bys may an stimativa a wra'n ow sikorra;
76 marow a'n lagha'm, pub an quisquilia 77 a veu Beatrice ow th'y splannder a'y lagha, 78 a wra'n ow splanndya a-dhia moy mildir:
79 rag henna my a welas moy wosa wosa; 80 ha marow owth ow th'y splannder my a vynnas 81 a-dro dhe'n peswara splannder a welas y'n mysk.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 E la mia donna: «Dentro da quei rai 83 vagheggia il suo fattor l’anima prima 84 che la prima virtù creasse mai».
query.result:
**English:**
82 And my lady: "Within those rays 83 the soul gazes upon its maker before 84 the first virtue ever created it".
**Cornish:**
82 Ha'gas benen: "Y'n mes an reow hyn 83 yth wragh an enef y'n gwrer an kynsa 84 kyns an kynsa vertus a veu gwrys erbyth".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Come la fronda che flette la cima 86 nel transito del vento, e poi si leva 87 per la propria virtù che la soblima,
88 fec’ io in tanto in quant’ ella diceva, 89 stupendo, e poi mi rifece sicuro 90 un disio di parlare ond’ ïo ardeva.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Like the branch that bends its top 86 in the passing of the wind, and then rises 87 by its own virtue that lifts it up,
88 so did I while she was speaking, 89 in wonder, and then a desire to speak 90 with which I burned made me confident again.
**Cornish:**
85 Kepar an aval a blyg y'n ben 86 y'n tremena an gwyns, ha'gas sevel 87 rag y honen vertus a'n syw sublym,
88 hemma me a wrug bys vyth a lever, 89 yn syndyans, ha'gas sevel onan dysyr 90 rag kommysa a wrug ow sevel sygur.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 E cominciai: «O pomo che maturo 92 solo prodotto fosti, o padre antico 93 a cui ciascuna sposa è figlia e nuro,
94 divoto quanto posso a te supplìco 95 perché mi parli: tu vedi mia voglia, 96 e per udirti tosto non la dico».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And I began: "O fruit that matured 92 alone, you were the ancient father 93 to whom every wife is daughter and daughter-in-law,
94 as devoutly as I can, I beg you 95 to speak to me: you see my desire, 96 and to hear you, I do not say it aloud".
**Cornish:**
91 Ha'gas a dhallathas: "O aval a dhewas 92 onan genys gwrys, o tas hen 93 dhe'gas pub prios yw mernans ha nuro,
94 devos bys vyth a allav ow suppliko 95 rag kommysa gansow: ty a wel ow dysyr, 96 ha'gas rag klevos ow nyns yw ow dyllo".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Tu vuogli udir quant’ è che Dio mi puose 110 ne l’eccelso giardino, ove costei 111 a così lunga scala ti dispuose,
112 e quanto fu diletto a li occhi miei, 113 e la propria cagion del gran disdegno, 114 e l’idïoma ch’usai e che fei.
query.result:
**English:**
109 You want to hear how long it has been since God placed me 110 in the lofty garden, where this one 111 set you on such a long stairway,
112 and how much delight was in my eyes, 113 and the real reason for the great disdain, 114 and the language that I used and what I did.
**Cornish:**
109 Ty a vyn gweles pyth yw an termyn a veu Duw ow posas 110 y'n gorden uhel, le may hy 111 ow'th disposas war an lel hir ma.
112 Ha'gas pyth oedh ow lowena dhe'gas ow hedhes, 113 ha'gas an gwir achos rag an disdeyn bras, 114 ha'gas an ydyom a usen ha'gas an tra veu ow thyo.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Or, figluol mio, non il gustar del legno 116 fu per sé la cagion di tanto essilio, 117 ma solamente il trapassar del segno.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Now, my son, it was not the tasting of the wood 116 that was in itself the cause of such exile, 117 but only the transgression of the boundary.
**Cornish:**
115 Wella, ow mab, nyns oedh an blasa an prenn 116 rag y honen an achos rag kemmysk essilyow, 117 mes onan genys an tremena an merk.

**English:**
118 From where your lady Virgil set out, 119 four thousand three hundred and two revolutions 120 of the sun I desired this council;
121 and I saw him return to all the lights 122 of his path nine hundred and thirty 123 times, while I was on earth.
**Cornish:**
118 A'gas le may ow mosas ow benen Virgili, 119 peswar mil tri cans ha'gas dew volom 120 a'n howl a vynnas ow an konsel ma.
121 Ha'gas ow'm gwelas ow torna dhe pub golonnow 122 a'n fordh y'n naw kans tressa ha'gas deg warn ugens 123 termyn, bys vyth oen ow war an nor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 La lingua ch’io parlai fu tutta spenta 125 innanzi che a l’ovra inconsummabile 126 fosse la gente di Nembròt attenta:
127 ché nullo effetto mai razïonabile, 128 per lo piacere uman che rinovella 129 seguendo il cielo, sempre fu durabile.
query.result:
**English:**
124 The language that I spoke was completely extinguished 125 before the people of Nimrod attempted 126 the unfinished work:
127 because no rational effect, 128 for the human pleasure that is renewed 129 following the heavens, was ever lasting.
**Cornish:**
124 An yeth a leveris oedh oll spenys 125 kyns ages dhe'gas dhe'n ober a-berfek 126 oedh an bobel a Nembròt ow tentos:
127 rag nyns eus effeyth bythkweth rasyonel, 128 rag an lowena denel a wra nowydh 129 ow sywya an nef, bythkweth oedh ow drehedhel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Opera naturale è ch’uom favella; 131 ma così o così, natura lascia 132 poi fare a voi secondo che v’abbella.
query.result:
**English:**
130 It is natural for man to speak; 131 but in this way or that, nature leaves it 132 up to you to do as you please.
**Cornish:**
130 Ober naturel yw rag denel leverel; 131 mes kepar ma po kepar ma, naturel a lell 132 wosa dhe'gas dhe wreyth kepar ha'gas a vyn.

**English:**
133 Before I descended to the infernal anguish, 134 He was called on earth the supreme good 135 from which comes the joy that envelops me;
136 and He was then called: and this is fitting, 137 because the custom of mortals is like a leaf 138 on a branch, which goes away and another comes.
**Cornish:**
133 Kyns vyth esedhaf dhe'n enebrasow, 134 Ev a veu gelwys war an nor an gwella, 135 A-dhyworth pyw an lowena a wra'm golgh.
136 Ha henna a veu gelwys wosa: ha henna yw coth, 137 Rag an defnydh a dusow yw kepar ha delyow 138 war gaven, ow tos ha mos ha mos ha dos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Nel monte che si leva più da l’onda, 140 fu’ io, con vita pura e disonesta, 141 da la prim’ ora a quella che seconda,
142 come ’l sol muta quadra, l’ora sesta».
query.result:
**English:**
139 On the mountain that rises highest from the waves, 140 I was, with a life that was pure and yet dishonorable, 141 from the first hour to that which is second,
142 as the sun changes quadrant, the sixth hour.
**Cornish:**
139 War an menydh a syr y’n ughella a’n tonnow, 140 Omov, gans bywans glan ha anvos, 141 A’n kynsa our dhe’n nessa,
142 Kepar ha’n howl ow chanjya kwadrans, an wheksa our.
